thread.title: New Look set to close 100 stores in bid to cut costs

author: Hannah Finch
title: New Look set to close 100 stores in bid to cut costs
text:
New Look set to close 100 stores in bid to cut costs Exeter lost its New Look Men store in September Share Alys Key, Press Association City Reporter Hannah Finch Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get Daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
New Look could close as many as 100 UK stores as part of a radical turnaround plan to cut costs and improve profitability.
The fashion retailer had already announced that 60 stores were marked for closure under a company voluntary arrangement (CVA) approved in March.
New Look has large stores in prime retail spots across Devon including Princesshay in Exeter, Torquay and Drake Circus in Plymouth with smaller stores in Paignton, Newton Abbot, Exmouth, Tiverton and Barnstaple.
In March, it said that branches in Torquay's Union Street and Sidmouth would be among the first 60 to close.
New Look Men in Princesshay closed in September and is set to be replaced by fashion store Oliver Bonas. New Look Men closure
Primark is going against the tide with figures showing a rise in its share of High Street shoppers. Read More
New Look executive chairman Alistair McGeorge said on Tuesday that the number which will definitely close after negotiations with landlords is at 85. The new Look in Torquay is one of the town's biggest shops (Image: Geograph)
Discussions are ongoing regarding a further 13 stores, of which Mr McGeorge said around half were likely to close.
The company’s new strategy has so far yielded higher profits, but sales continue to decline. Five reasons High Streets are struggling
We asked Lucinda Coleman, Business Recovery Partner at PKF Francis Clark and an expert in helping struggling retailers to find ways of restructuring their business to ride out the storm, to explain why the High Street has buckled under pressure.
1. Tight wallets
Consumer spending has had its weakest start to the year since 2012 seeing consumer spending falling -1.1% year – on- year, declining for the ninth time in ten months; face to face spend down -2.5% year- on- year and recreation and culture spending seeing its greatest decline since April 2010, according to the Visa UK Consumer Spending Index.
It is a stark reminder of just how tough it is for consumer-facing businesses.
2. Rising labour costs and business rates
Retailers and restaurants are facing a combination of costs such as the National Living Wage, Apprenticeship Levy and business rates, together with reduced consumer spending.
Many businesses are reluctant to pass on growing costs to their customers in the form of price rises but that eats into profits.
3. Narrow margins
Small and medium sized businesses operate on tighter budgets so they are likely to either lose money or raise prices which could result in a loss of custom. These tight margins and fragile finances show just how big the threat of insolvency will be in this sector.
4. Cost of ingredients
As the value of sterling has fallen, it has pushed up the price of imported goods including the price of food that we import. The UK imports around 50% of its food so many restaurants rely heavily on food and wine imports. With the cost of importing ingredients now higher and the increase in the cost of labour, due to the national minimum wage rises the sector is facing the perfect storm.
5. Competition
The restaurant sector is fiercely competitive with so much choice available. The rapid shift towards online shopping and meal delivery services has also taken a severe toll.
Now, when diners do venture out for a meal with their tightened purses the restaurant needs to do something to entice the customer into their establishment.
Figures released on Tuesday show that the company posted an underlying operating profit of £22.2 million for the first half, compared to a loss of £10.4 million in the same period last year.
But revenue declined by 4.2% to £656.9 million. Like-for-like sales under the New Look brand dropped by 3.7%, a slower rate than last year’s 8.6% drop.
The high-street mainstay said the slide in sales was in line with its plan to improve profitability with more full-price sales.
Speaking to the Press Association, Mr McGeorge said the first part of the recovery was going well, but that he would like to “move faster”.
“We’re not looking to defend our position, we’re looking to attack,” he said.
In addition to the restructuring of its UK base, New Look last month announced its decision to exit its retail business in China, where it has 148 stores. Read More Exeter has one of the healthiest High Streets in the county - and we live longer
Annualised cost savings of £70 million have now been achieved, with another £8 million to be added.
As part of the turnaround, New Look has also improved its UK market share and ramped up online operations, increasing click and collect sales by 41% in the first half.
Mr McGeorge warned that conditions on the high street remain challenging.
“We continue to work hard to accelerate our progress, but we are facing into significant headwinds and uncertainties, including Brexit,” he said. Read More
